raw_text:
Vodafone appoints new Japan boss
 
 Vodafone has drafted in its UK chief executive William Morrow to take charge of its troubled Japanese operation.
 
 Mr Morrow will succeed Shiro Tsuda as president of Vodafone KK, Japan's number three mobile operator, in April. Mr Tsuda, who will become chairman, was appointed president only two months ago but the business has struggled since then, losing customers in January. Vodafone had pinned its hopes on the launch of its 3G phones in November but demand for them has been slow.
 
 While it has more than 15 million customers in Japan, Vodafone has found it difficult to satisfy Japan's technologically demanding mobile users. It suffered a net loss of more than 58,000 customers in January, its second monthly reverse in the last year. "Vodafone is going to need to put a lot of money into Japan if it wants to rebuild the business," Tetsuro Tsusaka, a telecoms analyst with Deutsche Bank, told Reuters. "I do not know if it will be worth it for them to spend that kind of money just for Japan."
llama3.2:1b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow as new president of its Japanese operation in April. He will succeed Shiro Tsuda, who is stepping down after two months. Vodafone KK lost 58,000 customers in January and faces challenges in satisfying technologically demanding mobile users in Japan.
llama3.2:3b: Vodafone appoints William Morrow as new president of Vodafone KK, Japan, succeeding Shiro Tsuda who left after only two months due to business struggles. The company lost over 58,000 customers in January and has struggled to satisfy Japan's technologically demanding mobile users.
gemma2:2b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow as its new president in Japan.  Mr. Morrow will replace Shiro Tsuda, who had previously taken on the role but struggled to turn around Vodafone's performance in Japan after a loss of customers in January. The company is facing challenges due to slow 3G phone demand and needs significant investment to rebuild the business.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Vodafone appoints William Morrow as its new head of Japan. Mr Morrow succeeded Shiro Tsuda in the UK and has been appointed as president of Vodafone KK in Japan's mobile phone business. Despite having more than 15 million customers, Vodafone faces difficulties in keeping up with technologically demanding Japanese users, leading to a monthly loss of about 58,000 customers in January. The company is hoping to regain financial stability by spending more money on the market in Japan.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Vodafone appoints Morrow as new president in Japan; faces significant losses and struggle after Tsuda's promotion; aims to boost business by investing heavily; analysts doubt financial benefits.
qwen2.5:3b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow, its UK CEO, as the new president of Vodafone KK in Japan, replacing Shiro Tsuda who is now becoming chairman. Despite launching 3G phones in November, demand has been slow and the company has lost more than 58,000 customers since January. With over 15 million Japanese customers but facing difficulties due to tech-savvy users, Vodafone may need substantial investment to revive its business, with analyst Tetsuro Tsusaka questioning if it would be worthwhile just for Japan's market.
opencoder:1.5b: Vodafone appoints new Japan boss, Mr Morrow takes charge of its Japanese operation, while his successor is Shiro Tsuda, appointed president of Vodafone KK in April. However, the business has struggled since then due to loss of customers in January. The demand for 3G phones has been slow, but Japan's technologically demanding mobile users have also struggled. As a result, Vodafone has had a net loss of more than 58,000 customers during January and plans to put considerable funds into Japan if it continues to rebuild the business.

"I do not know if it will be worth it for them to spend that kind of money just for Japan."
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text concisely while preserving key ideas and details.

First, I'll identify the main points: Vodafone is appointing William Morrow as their new Japanese CEO. He replaces Shiro Tsuda, who was previously chairman but only two months ago. The previous president had a weak track record in Japan with slow customer uptake for 3G phones, which led to a net loss of over 58,000 customers in January.

I should focus on the key events and outcomes. Vodafone's strategy is clear: invest money in Japan if they want to rebuild their business. There's concern about the low demand from tech-savvy users but it's necessary for growth. The analyst also mentions potential financial strain but doesn't recommend spending just for Japan.

I need to ensure all critical information is included without unnecessary details. I'll structure the summary with clear headings and key terms so that it's easy to understand.
</think>

Vodafone has appointed William Morrow as its new Japanese CEO, replacing Shiro Tsuda, who was previously chairman but only two months ago. Mr. Morrow will take office in April, aiming to stabilize Vodafone's struggling Japanese operation. Vodafone had faced slow growth for 3G phones and lost over 58,000 customers in January, with a net loss of more than 58,000 due to the low demand from technologically demanding mobile users. Analyst Tetsuro Tsusaka noted that rebuilding their business may require significant investment in Japan, even if it costs money there. However, he remained cautious about spending solely for Japan.
tinyllama:1.1b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow as its new Japan boss. In his new role, he replaces Shiro Tsuda, who had previously been the company's president in Japan. The appointment is effective from April, and Mr Tsuda will become chairman of VoaFon's Japanese operations, which have been struggling with a declining customer base since January 2015. While VodaFone has over 16 million customers in Japan, the company struggled to satisfy Japan's technologically demanding mobile users. The appointment of Morrow is an effort by VodaFone to reboot its business in Japan, a country it has been targeting for some time now. Despite Mr Tsuda's earlier successes, the business is currently facing tough competition from other mobile carriers in the country and faces high costs for launching 3G phones.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow as president of its troubled Japanese operations. Morrow is currently the UK chief executive and will take charge in April, succeeding Shiro Tsuda as president. Vodafone had hoped to tap into the popularity of its 3G phones launched in November, but demand for them has been slow. In January alone, more than 58,000 customers lost their accounts, marking a net loss for the second month in a row. Despite these challenges, Morrow will be focused on delivering results for Vodafone KK, Japan's third largest mobile operator.
phi:2.7b: Vodafone appoints William Morrow as its new Japan CEO due to low demand for 3G phones and customer loss in January. The company plans to invest in Japan, but telecoms analyst Tetsuro Tsusaka is skeptical about the investment's worth.

However, the company has struggled since then, losing customers due to a slow demand for its 3G phones. Vodafone had pinned its hopes on the launch of its 3G phones but demand for them has been slow. Despite having more than 15 million customers in Japan, Vodafone has faced difficulties in satisfying Japan's technologically demanding mobile users. The company lost a net loss of more than 58,000 customers in January, its second monthly reverse in the last year. Analysts believe that Vodafone will need to spend a lot of money to rebuild its business in Japan, but it is still uncertain if it is worth it for them to spend that kind of money just for Japan.

Tsuda, who will become chairman, had only been in the role for two months, during which the company lost customers. Despite having over 15 million users in Japan, Vodafone has struggled to meet the country's high technological expectations. stablelm2:1.6b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow as CEO of its Japanese operation, replacing Shiro Tsuda, who becomes chairman after serving two months. The company faces challenges in satisfying tech-savvy Japanese customers due to launch issues and losing customers. Vodafone's investment in the market is crucial for rebuilding the business.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Vodafone has appointed William Morrow, its UK CEO, as the new president of Vodafone KK in April, succeeding Shiro Tsuda. This move comes after Mr. Tsuda, who became president two months prior, faced challenges leading the company's second-largest mobile operator in Japan, which has been losing customers since November due to slow demand for 3G phones. Despite having over 15 million Japanese subscribers, Vodafone struggles to meet technologically sophisticated user expectations and suffered a net loss of more than 58,000 customers in January, marking its second monthly decline in the past year. Telecoms analyst Tetsuro Tsusaka predicts Vodafone may need significant investment to revitalize the Japanese market, questioning whether such expenditure would be profitable given the market's challenges.
reference: While it has more than 15 million customers in Japan, Vodafone has found it difficult to satisfy Japan's technologically demanding mobile users.Mr Tsuda, who will become chairman, was appointed president only two months ago but the business has struggled since then, losing customers in January.Mr Morrow will succeed Shiro Tsuda as president of Vodafone KK, Japan's number three mobile operator, in April.Vodafone has drafted in its UK chief executive William Morrow to take charge of its troubled Japanese operation.
